title: Thursday, 18th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Whoa! We've got pretty much everything this morning

PM11:01am

Stocks tanking

PM11:01am

Political chaos in the US

11:01 am
PM11:01am

A big hostile bid

PM11:01am

Loads of trading statements

PM11:01am

Morning, btw

11:01 am
PM11:02am

Welcome to Markets Live

PM11:02am

Could start with something to read rather than us

PM11:02am

Ed Luce on the Republicans

11:02 am
PM11:02am

https://www.ft.com...-821a-6027b8a20f23

PM11:02am

Actually, you can just listen to that

PM11:02am

What is this, is it new?

11:02 am
PM11:03am

PM11:03am

Text-to-speech

PM11:03am

Saves you having to move your eyes, I guess

11:03 am
PM11:03am

Seems to work. The voice is rather natural

PM11:04am

Has someone had to record that article or is it computer generated?

PM11:04am

I will ahve to ask someone

11:04 am
undefined
PM11:04am

But we have other things to discuss

PM11:04am

Footsie currently off a ton

11:04 am
PM11:04am

102 points to be precise

PM11:04am

Just holding above 7400 for now

PM11:05am

Meanwhile, the former krona has gone thru 1.30

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Just as people are planning trips to France etc

PM11:05am

Which is nice

PM11:05am

But hey, rude to pass up the chance to talk dirty laundery

11:05 am
Berendsen PLC (BRSN:LSE): Last: 1,059, up 195.5 (+22.64%), High: 1,129, Low: 1,050, Volume: 3.52m
PM11:06am

You've long been a close follower of Berendsen Bryce

BE11:06am

I have!

11:06 am
PM11:06am

Well, closer than anyone else in this building

PM11:06am

that's for sure

PM11:06am

here's the bid rejection: http://www.investe...1705180830585260F/

11:07 am
PM11:07am

very significantly undervalues Berendsen and its prospects. Berendsen does not see the basis for any further discussions with Elis.

PM11:07am

I've got to confess that I only know about Berendsen cos of you Bryce -- and I don't know anything about Elis at all

PM11:07am

Well, i didnt

11:07 am
PM11:08am

http://www.elis.com/en/

BE11:08am

Well .... Yes, the lack of interest in a multi-billion cross-border linen bear hug does seem somewhat incongruous.

BE11:08am

Perhaps it might be worth recapping how we've reached this point.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

And apologies to anyone who already knows the history. But it seems you're in the minority.

BE11:08am

So! So, Peter Ventress retired mid 2015 after five years as Berendsen CEO.

BE11:09am

He was succeeded by James Drummond, whose previous job was to tart up and sell Avincis on behalf of KKR.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

You'll remember Avincis. It was the cut-and-shunt helicopter services merger thing that Babcock bought in 2014.

PM11:09am

o..k

BE11:09am

Now, it's difficult to see what shape Avincis was in at the point of purchase, because its oil and gas business pretty much immediately.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

O&G was 30% of its revenue and was on a much higher margin to the rest of the business. Then, overnight, it wasn't. And Babcock was left looking a bit silly.

BE11:10am

Anyway, that wasn't Drummond's concern. He'd moved over to Berendsen, where he started doing what he knew best.

BE11:11am

Ie., he sacked a lot of middle management and sent a lot of memos about performance targets.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

Then came the profit warnings. October and March.

BE11:11am

Which were blamed on historic underinvestment.

PM11:11am

Nice

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Though some questioned whether it might more be down to losing a lot of customer relationship knowledge and relying too much on accountants who ran the business rather too hot.

BE11:12am

Because the linens business is hospitality, largely, and hospitality has its own peculiarities that are unlikely to be visible on a management spreadsheet.

BE11:12am

Stifel's sell note on Berendsen from back in December remains the definitive work on the company.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

The narrative is that it is mainly a company issue not a market one, with a striking difference in culture and approach compared to the best performing parts of the group. UK flat linen was historically driven by a relentless drive to reduce costs with not enough customer focus. Investment was held back as prior management could not see returns meeting hurdle rates. This resulted in some slow and modest margin erosion, but the business was well run operationally within these parameters.

BE11:12am

A new strategy based on a directed cultural shift with more emphasis on customer service as well as an extension of lean production techniques to the Hospitality segment in FY17 and Healthcare in FY18. Investment is being ramped-up, but returns are still to be defined. We have reservations about the appropriateness of dogmatic application of six sigma change to many of BRSN's operations. BRSN is, above all, a people’s business with significant value in local operational management. This is being tinkered with.

BE11:13am

The strength, consistency and transparency of cash flows were one of the hallmarks of BRSN. Under Mr. Ventress’ tenure, cash conversion averaged 120% (free cash flow to net income) and post tax ROIC rose 290bps to 10.3%. Following leadership change, cash conversion targets have been lowered (from +100% to 75%-90%) as capex is increased. The rate of CL2000 plant conversion is being trebled; the UK flat linen businesses (Hospitality and Facility) are seeing increased investment. New areas of growth, which were identified in the November 2015 strategy update, are requiring some upfront investment. Not only are we not convinced that BRSN’s current strategic journey will see it achieve faster organic growth with returns rising faster than would have been achieved under the prior strategy, we are also concerned that the group is reaching too far to deliver the raised growth objectives, becoming distracted from day-to-day delivery of operational improvements.

11:12 am
PM11:13am

This is genuinely interesting Bryce

BE11:13am

See!

BE11:13am

Laundry's interesting, if you know where to look.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

So anyway, here we are.

BE11:13am

ELIS bid ~£11.00 (£4.40 in cash and 0.411 new shares, an implied 31% premium) in late April and was rejected on May 12.

BE11:13am

Elis bid again, ~£11.75 (£4.40 in cash and 0.426 shares, implied 36% premium) on May 16 and was rejected without engagement.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

That's an offer of £2.05bn.

BE11:13am

EV of just over 14 times current-year EBITDA, by consensus forecasts.

BE11:14am

Which is ... I mean, it's not really that low is it?

11:14 am
BE11:14am

One can argue that Berendsen's current year EBITDA is depressed by front-loading the investment on new machines and stuff. Or you can take another view.

PM11:14am

I was trying to see the precise wording of the Elis statement -- but their website has blocked me, as if I'm american or something

PM11:15am

But this is a bear hug, right?

11:14 am
BE11:15am

This is.

PM11:15am

Statement wasn't prompted by a leak

PM11:15am

Or was it?

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Nope. No leak. Berendsen has been down every day since the offer, I think.

PM11:15am

Goodness

BE11:16am

So Berendsen board think shareholders all want to keep betting that Drummond's infatuation with the Six Sigma Handbook will help stabilise this thing. They believe this so much they chose not to even ask them.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Elis, meanwhile, thinks the might want 35% of a bigger group, plus quite a lot of cash in an offer that adds up to an immediate 36% premium.

BE11:17am

It's a bit tricky not to side with Elis here, isn't it? Although I'm sure by saying this I'm in for a re-education from the Berendsen Feltcollaredsource later.

PM11:17am

They are largely French, tho

11:17 am
BE11:17am

So. Here's RBC.

BE11:17am

In our view, this looks an attractive price for the group - we have continued concerns about the scale of the group’s capex plans and its ability to turnaround its UK operations and are therefore surprised at the Board's non-engagement with Elis. In our recent Textile Rental Note (27th March, Material Differences), we set out a blue-sky scenario for Berendsen factoring in a return to normalized margin levels and putting valuations in line with peers, and we struggled to justify a valuation much above 870p - £11.73 therefore looks a good offer given the uncertainty in the business at present.

BE11:18am

.... and maybe Barclays, once my PC starts working again.

11:19 am
PM11:19am

Notice that Yoel Zaoui is one of the advisers

BE11:19am

The proposal equates to a 2016A EV/EBITDA of 7.2x (towards the peak of BRSN’s 10 yr trading range) and an EV/EBITA of 15.6x (given the difficulties currently impacting BRSN’s UK business, the implied multiple for FY17F EV/EBITA of 17.3x). The approach has been rejected by the BRSN Board (as was an original offer, which was not made public, on 28 April at 1100p per share) and hence Elis has decided to make the offer public “so that it can be considered by BRSN’s shareholders”. The proposal makes geographic sense to us with Berendsen strong in UK and Scandinavia, and Elis strong in France, while in areas where there is currently overlap, there would be opportunities for footprint rationalization in Benelux while also creating a business of proper scale in Germany which is an area both companies are relatively underweight on a standalone basis (density matters in this business). The announcement outlines synergies of “at least €40m pa” by the end of the third year and estimates double digit earnings accretion on an adj EPS basis. Could this proposal flush out other interested parties? While it cannot be ruled out, we think another buyer would find it hard to match Elis’s proposed synergies given the geographic fit. Given (i) our question marks over BRSN’s current capital allocation strategy (as outlined in Berendsen: Execution risk; downgrade to UW, 21 March 2017); (ii) the potential consolidation happening elsewhere in European workwear; in our view today’s proposal is worthy of consideration.

BE11:20am

Who's Yoel Zaoui?

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Him and his brother Michael are interesting

BE11:20am

Oh! Zaoui & Co! Sorry, of course.

PM11:20am

They've done huge amounts of M&A last few years

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Guthrie did an interview with them a while back

PM11:20am

Here: https://www.ft.com...-8efb-00144feabdc0

PM11:20am

But sorry, i interrupt

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Actually, you didn't. I think that's probably sufficient for laundry.

PM11:22am

Guess its a story that will roll on for a while yet

PM11:22am

We think the bid is well aimed

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Hold on, I clicked on a Peel Hunt note and have waited a minute so far for it to open.

BE11:23am

I'm not giving up yet.

PM11:23am

Beresden got Caz defending them, btw

11:23 am
PM11:23am

And HSBC

PM11:23am

And the felt whole be calling you is Richard Mountain -- FTI

BE11:23am

Great!

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:24am

The price, which represents a 36% premium to the closing price on 17 May 2017, equates to 19.9x 2017E EPS and 7.4x 2017E EBITDA. In addition, the implied 2016 EV/EBITA of 15.6x is above the 15.2x valuation of Rentokil’s workwear & hygiene businesses transferring into the Haniel JV.

BE11:24am

We await developments with interest.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Thanks, Peel Hunt.

undefined
PM11:24am

We should run thru some of these trading statements

11:24 am
PM11:24am

Burberry top of the Footsie gainers

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,686, up 45 (+2.74%), High: 1,688, Low: 1,628, Volume: 643.17k
PM11:25am

http://www.investe...1705180700144813F/

11:24 am
PM11:25am

Bit of a surprise

BE11:25am

Well, if you lowball expectations it's easier to beat them.

PM11:25am

this is true

11:25 am
BE11:26am

The headlines are reassuring, in their way. Numbers above, cost cutting in line.

PM11:26am

Christopher Bailey giving up the reins as ceo soon, of course

PM11:26am

Not sure how that will work

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Perhaps his exit explains the sheen given to the numbers, because below the headlines it's still not good.

PM11:01am

Soaraway sterling

BE11:28am

Oh! But but you get a share buyback.

11:28 am
PM11:29am

Doubling the share buy back, i think

BE11:29am

Because that's what Burberry should be using its money for, right? A single brand mid-luxury retailer should be spending £300m on buying back its own shares rather than investing in its flatlining business.

BE11:29am

Here's UBS to go through the figures.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: FY17 adjusted PBT of £462m is in line (UBSe: £460m) and DPS of 38.9p +5% y/y is slightly ahead (UBSe 38p). Net cash of £809m is significantly better (UBSe £611m).
Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: There is a new share buyback of £300m for FY18 (c.4% of market cap). Free cash flow generation beat through a combination of a cash inflow from working capital (including inventories -3% underlying) and lower capex from delayed spend.
Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: No change to underlying outlook for FY18 but the recent GBP strength impacts adj. PBT by £20m since the trading update implying consensus moves to £450m (£470m previously). Capex guided at £140m (UBSe £150m).
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: With FY17 PBT in line, we expect a positive response from the market to the better cash position, additional buyback and higher dividend.

BE11:30am

And RBC, to sum up the sell case.

BE11:31am

We expect FY18 to be another year of pedestrian sales and earnings growth for Burberry, materially below sector average. Low single-digit retail LFL growth should not be enough to generate meaningful operating leverage and this should put a lid on margin expansion. Potential corporate activity and GBP changes are key risks to our thesis.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

And there's not a lot more to say, really.

undefined
PM11:32am

We;'ve lost the Rabble to some discussion about wafer technology

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Oh well.

PM11:32am

What's going on?

BE11:33am

Um ........ the wafer supply thing is probably beyond our scope here.

11:33 am
PM11:33am

Let's do Royal Mail instead then

Royal Mail PLC (RMG:LSE): Last: 437.70, up 6.9 (+1.60%), High: 450.50, Low: 430.20, Volume: 3.25m
PM11:34am

Another reasonably strong performer in a serious down market

11:34 am
PM11:34am

Again on beating subdued expectations

PM11:34am

?

PM11:34am

http://www.investe...1705180700164819F/

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Yep. Numbers are okay. And mostly irrelevant to the investment case.

BE11:35am

Which is about pensions and wage negotiations, with the kicker longer term of whether growth in the competitive world of parcel volumes can offset shrinkage in the noncompetitive world of letter delivery.

BE11:36am

That's been the story since it floated though. We can't recap it every single quarter.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

Here's Cantor with a summary of the figures.

BE11:36am

Our view: RMG has reported solid full year earnings with a small beat at operating profit. The core UKPIL business traded inline but GLS European parcels performed strongly, helped by weaker Sterling. Recent acquisitions in this division are integrating well. The outlook statement is mixed and despite the beat we do not expect any significant forecast upgrades today. RMG’s valuation is attractive, trading on a 2017e PE of c.11x vs. the sector on 13x (a 15% discount); with a forecast dividend yield of 5.5%. We think that RMG will only become really attractive to investors with a clearer growth plan. The Group also has the pressing issue of pension plan restructuring to resolve this year. We maintain our HOLD rating.

· 2016-17 earnings – Group revenue was up 1% on an underlying basis and growth in GLS more than offset the decline in core UKPIL revenue. Group revenue was £9.78bn vs. the consensus forecast for £9.6bn (+1.9%). Adjusted operating profit was £712m vs. the consensus forecast for £694m (+2.6%). EPS was 44.1p vs. the consensus forecast for 40.9p (+7.8%). DPS was 23p vs. the consensus forecast for 23p (inline). In the UKPIL division adjusted operating profit was £548m vs. £537m (+2%). UK parcel revenue increased by 3% with 3% volume growth but UK letters revenue declined by 5% with a 6% decline in addressed letters. UKPIL cost control was tight with a 1% reduction in operating costs. Mixed performance in UKPIL was offset by a strong performance in GLS (European parcels), revenue and volume were both up 9%. Higher revenues in this division were helped by weaker Sterling. GLS operating profit was £164m vs. consensus £155m (+5.8%). The Group is past the peak of capex with net cash investment of £492m compared to £656m in 2015-16. However, net debt increased to £338m with the acquisition by GLS of Golden State Overnight and ASM parcel carriers.

BE11:36am

· Outlook and forecasts – RMG has provided no hard financial targets but states that it will continue to focus on sustainable cash generation. The Group will also continue to invest in GLS’ focused international expansion. RMG remains on track to avoid £600m of annualised operating costs in UKPIL. Capex will continue to decline with £450m guided for 2017-18. That said addressed letter volume decline is expected to be at higher end of the range of decline (4-6%) in 2017-18 “if business uncertainty persists”. Consensus forecasts for 2017-18 are: revenue £9.76bn, adjusted operating profit £673m (-6% y-o-y), EPS 39.7p and DPS 23.8p. Despite the small beat today we expect forecasts to remain largely unchanged at this time.

· Valuation – RMG is trading on a calendar 2017e PE of 11x vs. the sector on 13x, or a 15% discount. Our estimated dividend yield is 5.5%; this is attractive with the sector offering 3.5%. The stock has lagged the FTSE 100 by c.20% in the past six months mainly due to uncertainty on pension matters and weaker trading in the UK core businesses.

· Risks & TP – Demand for parcels & mail, wages, industrial action, pension liabilities and associated service costs, and regulation issues by Ofcom. Our TP is derived using a 10-year DCF of net cash flows, our target price is 500p.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

And Liberum.

BE11:37am

The results were ahead of consensus, albeit with the latter having been cut steadily through the year. The decline is Letters volumes is expected to be at the worse end of the long-term range (down 4-6%), but management expects Parcels volumes to track market growth (+3%). Progress on costs is expected to continue, although management is flagging some headwinds. We remain concerned about the intensity of competition in the UK parcels market, and there are still risks in agreeing new pension arrangements.

BE11:37am

On our current published estimates, Royal Mail trades on a March 2018E P/E of 10.8x, EV/EBITDA of 5.4x and dividend yield of 5.7%. Also these multiples may appear undemanding at first glance, in our view the valuation is not attractive relative to the limited growth prospects of the group and the pensions risk. Our recommendation remains SELL with a 400p target price based on our DCF valuation.

11:38 am
undefined
PM11:39am

Albert's out -- admitting he wrong

PM11:39am

But it's on US wage data -- not admitting that he's generally wrong

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Getting it wrong is a tricky thing to admit in this business. When I was on the buy-side in the mid-1980s, I marvelled how sell-side macro analysts managed to perform a 180 degree handbrake turn in their stance while pretending that had been their view all along! It was a finely honed skill that necessitated both bravado and barefaced cheek. In an industry not big on humility, admitting you are wrong is not something to do if you want to survive. This myopia also extends to central bankers with some very notable and rare exceptions. Now that I have had my cataract operation and my own -17.0 short-sightedness has been eliminated, I can admit that I am bemused by the recent benign US wage data - as measured by average hourly earnings. I had expected it to roar like a lion, but instead it has been as gentle as a lamb. Am I wrong?

PM11:39am

I will leave it there.

PM11:39am

Don't worry

11:39 am
PM11:39am

Actually, it looks an interesting long-ish read from him

PM11:40am

Will look at it later

undefined
11:40 am
BE11:41am

(@Flaneur: I didn't reckon that. Berenberg forecast that, I think by extrapolating the Baker report. I can dig out their working if you like.)

BE11:41am

Moving away from results for a second ......

PM11:41am

Please do

11:41 am
BE11:42am

RBC knife-catching TalkTalk is about the only sellside call worth noting.

BE11:42am

Thursdays are always a bit low on sellside due to the results wave.

BE11:42am

It's a valuation call, really.

11:42 am
Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 180.13, up 5.53 (+3.17%), High: 185.90, Low: 178.00, Volume: 2.58m
BE11:42am

We believe the combination of the recent share price fall and the outlook for subs growth (driven by the mechanical impact of FLPP on churn) leaves a clear opportunity for investors willing to take a 12-18m view. Backing out B2B valuation of £1.1bn puts the consumer business on a market implied EV of just c.£300/sub - very attractive in our view for a mobile operator wanting instant scale in broadband.

BE11:42am

Our thinking: We are upgrading TalkTalk to Outperform with a raised 225p price target from 185p. Although there are longer term question marks over TalkTalk's ability to grow the business as it is squeezed by BT, Sky and the mobile operators, we see a clear opportunity for investors willing to take a 12-18m view.

Subscriber momentum: In our view TalkTalk's recent share price fall offers an attractive, almost asymmetric, opportunity. As we detail in the note, subscriber growth should start to come through as the impact of subscribers re-contracting to Talk's new Fixed Low Price Plans (FLPP) which have 18 month contracts. Having started in October, already 1m (c.33%) subscribers have re-contracted. The impact of wholesale mix was clearly negative last year and masked an underlying increase in Retail ARPU (details in note). With the significant drag effect of wholesale mix lessening, the outlook for revenue is set to improve. We believe such a positive momentum in key subscriber metrics is not reflected in the share price.

Business valuation: we now break out the value of the B2B business separately as we believe this is a valuable, and potentially separable, part of TalkTalk. At some £300m of revenue, it is one of the largest independent UK B2B operators and it is still growing. Critically if we apply a 14x EBITDA multiple to the business (not dissimilar to smaller Gamma Telecom), the market derived valuation for the consumer business is just c.£300 per sub. In our view that is a very attractive price for a mobile operator looking to gain instant scale in broadband and convergence.

Estimates: We have upgraded our FY2018E revenue by 0.4% and EBITDA by 3.0%. For FY2019E, revenue rises by 0.9% and EBITDA by 1.1%.

11:42 am
PM11:43am

hmm

BE11:43am

We have a price target of 225p based on a discounted cash flow (DCF) to value the consumer business and a trading multiple of 14x EV/EBITDA to value the B2B business. This multiple is a slight premium to its closest peer, reflecting TalkTalk's growth and substantial scale. The consumer DCF uses a weighted cost of capital of 8.5% with modest perpetual growth assumptions (1.0%). The return implied by our price target supports an Outperform rating.

PM11:43am

Hinting at spinning or selling the B2B side?

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Not an idea I'd heard before, and I'd be surprised if Dunstone pursued a breakup. He's not that type.

BE11:45am

Otherwise, though, RBC's argument seems fair enough. It's not that it's a dramatically different business, or even anything other a deeply troubled one. It's just quite cheap.

undefined
11:45 am
PM11:45am

Just remember that Kadhim's up for the young Wincott award today

PM11:45am

But he faces tough competition

PM11:45am

http://www.wincott.co.uk/

11:45 am
PM11:46am

Still, gets a white glove lunch at Mansion House

PM11:46am

Young Financial Journalist of the Year

Mike Bird, The Wall Street Journal
Kadhim Shubber, FT Alphaville
Aime Williams Financial Times

PM11:46am

Aime's very good as well

11:46 am
PM11:46am

Good award to win, that

PM11:46am

Just look at the past winners

PM11:47am

Anyway, Bryce we need to be prepared to raise a glass at No ! Lombard later

11:47 am
PM11:47am

Perhaps

undefined
BE11:48am

That's a seriously good shortlist! For a dying industry, we do seem to attract some surprisingly bright people.

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Anyway, what next?

PM11:48am

hmm

PM11:48am

Too many results

11:48 am
PM11:49am

And when the markets off 103 points....

PM11:49am

Footsie still holding above 7400 but only just

BE11:49am

It feels more like a proper selloff now.

11:49 am
PM11:50am

You know how market reporters have to come up with multiple ways to say the same thing....

BE11:50am

God, yes. I certainly do.

PM11:50am

Well, Bloomberg's come up with a new one

11:50 am
PM11:50am

Which you are going to have to adopt Bryce (not)

PM11:50am

World's 500 Richest People Lose $35 Billion From Trump Turmoil

PM11:50am

The world’s richest people lost $35 billion Wednesday when global equity markets were rocked by political turmoil in the U.S., according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

11:50 am
PM11:51am

Bill Gates, the world’s richest person with $86.8 billion, lost $1 billion as shares of Microsoft Corp., his largest holding, tumbled 2.8 percent, the most in almost a year. Amazon.com Inc. co-founder Jeff Bezos, who came within $4 billion of taking the top spot from Gates earlier this week, dropped to No. 3 after losing $1.7 billion as shares of the online retailer slid 2.2 percent. Spanish retailing tycoon Amancio Ortega lost $355 million to end the day in the second position with $83.2 billion.

BE11:51am

Oh, that one. They run their own list that adjusts net wealth minute by minute.

BE11:51am

When they launched it I think we proposed on here a Wrist List.

11:51 am
PM11:51am

hehe -- yes

PM11:52am

BE11:52am

Find out what watch the richest people were wearing. Public sightings. Perhaps put the info on a blockchain or whatever.

11:52 am
PM11:52am

There was a russian-focused site doing this i think

BE11:52am

Use wrist-weights that as a gauge of net worth, as it's just as relevant as any other.

undefined
11:53 am
BE11:53am

Hargreaves mentioned several times on the right.

Hargreaves Lansdown PLC (HL.:LSE): Last: 1,328, down 19 (-1.41%), High: 1,380, Low: 1,276, Volume: 1.34m
BE11:54am

Results okay, but it's another excuse to chew over the Vanguard problem.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Let's start with the panglossian take. Shore Cap.

BE11:55am

We think the ten month trading update from Hargreaves Lansdown (HL), issued today, will remind investors that Vanguard-based obituaries could prove somewhat premature. We raise our fair value from 1530p to 1575p and reiterate our BUY recommendation. We would regard the current share price weakness as an excellent opportunity to gain exposure to one of most impressive business model anywhere in the UK market

BE11:56am

So. Figures bare what they are. Mike Evans is off soon, meaning the entire C-Suite has been rotated within two years.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

But more importantly ......

BE11:56am

Much has been made of the launch, earlier this week, of Vanguard’s UK direct-to-client (D2C) platform. It will charge a platform fee of 15bps p.a. alongside the charges on the underlying Vanguard (passive-only) products which would take the all-in charge to around 30bps (varies a little depending on the mix of products). This compares to HL’s current platform fee of 45bps (on funds) up to a value of £250k. However, we commented yesterday that the HL’s AuA contains a low single digit % of passive investments and, with an average client balance of £82k (in a mixture of ISA/SIPP tax wrappers and also often including individual securities), we don’t think that switching the passive element to Vanguard would pass any kind of convenience test for the vast majority of clients. We see the Vanguard product as much more of a threat to the fledgling robo-advice providers.
